item.title: Random thoughts
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: Where do you send your letters when you no longer know where to send them?   Do you just cast them off to the cloud?

item.title: First idea
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: It's the start of the school year and some problems will be back. Like people who leave stuff on the sink. One of my ideas uses the concept of sensor on the bottom of the sink. If it goes beyond a certain weight. No water can be released by the faucet. I know this seems to defeat the purpose of actually washing the dishes in hindsight. But maybe it might be enough incentive for people to actually wash the dishes. I remember during water shortages back home, water was only available on certain times of the day. This meant everyone was done with the dishes, cooking, bathing and so on before 9pm and we'd all be sleeping early. Another is for people to actually put the deposit bottles in the right bin. Sometimes there are just too many bins on the floor that it's sometimes confusing on what goes in which bin. But what if there's a pot of money based on the deposit money collected from the bottles deposited.

item.title: The most disturbing toy I've ever seen
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: We are all familiar with Barbie dolls and any other doll that represents the female figure that is given to girls to play with as a toy. Each toy may have intended secondary motive such as either teaching you on how to color coordinate your clothes or just plain fun. Dolls come another set of clothes, shoes and accessories. Something that every girl should have. But this toy has one thing I have never seen in the many years I have spent in toy stores. This is intentionally named "Teenage Pregnancy Beautiful". SEROUSLY!?! The dolls is basically everything that Barbie is but this one is PREGNANT!  Coupled with a tiny baby inside the doll's belly. Something must have been lost in translation as this toy was made in China and eventually sold in the Philippines and apparently people are buying this toy. I was afraid to ask why they were buying this toy and apparently it sells well for the simple fact. IT'S WEIRD!!  Though some people who buy this rarely give it to their children but instead keep it for them for the sheer novelty. It boggles my mind why someone would actually make a toy like this. They can name this toy any way they like. But I still believe that it is wrong and disturbing.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Great info, thank you. I would just to point out that even the Mayo clinic says that moderate exercise while pregnant can be helpful.
Helloo we l0ve your theme alot favorited ya! thank y0u

item.title: INAMAZON
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: INAMAZON is a modification of the word "Amazon" in Filipino to mean to pass through Amazon in which I am referring to the online retailer which refers to anything purchased online. Much like the name Xerox. The use of brand names in Filipino culture is much easier to refer to the products or services introduced into the country rather than act itself which is photocopy.

item.title: Kitchen theory
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced

item.title: monochromatic vision
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: The way I see how a computer would see things would be in black and white. This image is me in my apartment while my other computer is on my work table behind me while I watch television.  I sometimes have a nagging feeling that the computer camera is sometimes watching me yet it does nothing. In photography, even in the digital form black and white or monochromatic images are much better is capturing the best quality no matter how advanced the sensor of the camera may be. Black and white is what I believe similar to the ones and zeros that computers deal with everyday.  This is in part of the the only thing the imaging chip has to worry about is black or white and the gray spectrum in between. Basing it on Ansel Adam's zone system, the monochromatic range is wider than that of the visible color range. In my opinion, the greater the resolution, the greater the depth, the more the camera is able to see. The more the camera sees, the more a connected computer can parse that data.   Link here

item.title: The eye
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: I'm proud to say that I grew up in the age of film. I had my first film camera which was a 110 film camera and I took my first pictures. But to see my work I had to give them to my father who then had the film developed which would usually take me a week at least to get my prints back. This childhood of mine is no longer possible in the current generation. I still remember the first time I had a digital camera and now the resolution my camera had back then is in my smart phone. How far have we gone in 20 years. Now cameras are everywhere, any child can operate a digital camera and most people are not aware of what these things can possibly do. In our Computational Camera's class last semester where we were asked what these cameras could do, I think the end of the world would be triggered by X-ray glassses. Image courtesy of flickr user jbcurio I'm not sure yet on where to take this. I'll expand this in a later post.

item.title: The machine language of games
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded:
The initial paragraph of the reading caught my eye where machines will actually write things for us that we can understand.

  “the most ignorant person, at a reasonable charge, and with a little bodily labour, might write books in philosophy, poetry, politics, laws, mathematics, and theology, without the least assistance from genius or study.”   

My answer to this would actually be Livejournal but as the text continues. I could relate this in the early days of videogame production with Japanese videogames in particular. My family grew up surrounded by poorly translated Japanese robot cartoons alongside Japanese videogames where there were no available translations to English. If there were, it usually looked like this.  Most famously known meme, "All your base are belong to us." I have never played the game but the meme has stuck with gamers . Reading through the wikipedia entry, it lists side by side the comparison with the original Japanese text alongside the translation of the game as it appeared and an accurate translation of the text. I can only imagine what went through the translation process. But if I were to analyze it, it would have probably just a guy with a Japanese to English dictionary just plain copying what was on screen without any context. Today's videogames have vastly improved with teams of Japanese and English translators thus bringing everything into context. On to the next step, have the machine translate things for us. I've been playing a MMORPG since 2003 called Final Fantasy XI Online. It's pretty unique in such a way that they do not separate users by country or language. Which means you can be playing alongside players who can only speak, English, Japanese, German, French and so on. With this in mind, the game developers created an auto translate function in the game to allow players to interact with those they could not normally play with. Though most users have used the service. It is by no means a point of lenghtly conversation but instead bridges the communication gap to be able to play. This type of machine generated text provided more tawdry phrases from the users like,

{Galka}  {meat}  {rod}  {Do you need it?}

As for myself actually experiencing machine produced text would be my current game on my Nintendo 3DS. I will bring to class to demonstrate. In the game Final Fantasy Theathrythm is a music game that adds a twist to playing it. You play through the music while replaying scenes from classic FInal Fantasy games. You choose characters and level them up as you play. Before each "battle", instead of a regular loading screen, a dynamic screen pops out that generates text based on the characters you choose (sometimes) and displays a phase that is sometimes coherent or utter nonsense. The text goes on and on with every gameplay. It might be just trying to play into the quirkyness of Japanese English. But this text placed in the context of the Final Fantasy franchise will make sense. Could we just be lacking the knowledge to comprehend the text delivered by these machines? Or is it the machine trying to tell us something?  Which brings me to Watson.  Watson is an IBM supercomputer built to understand the human language and interact with it. It has a database filled with encyclopedic and dictionary facts as well as human nuances which brings it's comprehension and statements generated during the gameshow "Jeopardy" is almost amazing. I say almost because he still got a number of questions really wrong. But the evidence is clear. The future is here. Watson is amalgamation of Jonathan Swift's writing machine, Bill Chamberlain's RACTER, and Christian Bök's Robopoetics personified Susan Blackmore's scenario of the "third replicator". Though I long for the computer aboard the USS Enterprise. Watson is definitely a step towards it.

item.title: Central Park walk
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: While walking around Central Park yesterday to shoot for our Big Screens project this semester we came upon this. It's a section of The Lake over here. View Larger Map Apparently it's caused by the warm summer weather and current cooler conditions as well as water currents has driven all the algae in the Lake to this corner. I wasn't too happy with the image so I went for the black and white effect. I'm curious to know which feels better.

item.title: A test of faith
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded:
I've been preoccuped this week with recent developments back home which make what I am doing probably illegal in my home country. Which makes me even more compelled to blog about it.  The Philippine government has enacted into law Republic Act 10175 or also known as the "Cybercrime Prevention Act of 2012". Originally drafted to crimminalize certain offenses made via digital means such as identity theft, spamming, cybersex and child pornography. There are no previous laws tackling this issue in the digital realm which makes these pretty much updating dating the current laws. However a line has been included that many find disturbing and that is the libel clause. I'll save you the trouble and fast forward through the pdf link above to page 7 on the pdf or page 13 of the scanned pages and read section 19.

Sec. 19. Restricting or Blocking Access to Computer Data - When a computer data in prima facie found to be in violation of this Act, the DOJ* shall issue an order to restrict or block access to such computer data.  *Department of Justice

This basically means, they don't need a court order to shut the internet, SMS, mobile phones and anything that is in a digital medium down if they see fit. Not to mention that the penalties for commiting online libel is harsher than traditional media libel (newspapers, radio, tv) which ranges from 1 Million pesos (roughly USD $25,000) and/or 12 years in prison.  With this in mind I'll refer to the 1987 Philippine Constituition which states in Article III, Section 3 and 4,

Section 3. (1) The privacy of communication and correspondence shall be inviolable except upon lawful order of the court, or when public safety or order requires otherwise as prescribed by law. (2) Any evidence obtained in violation of this or the preceding section shall be inadmissible for any purpose in any proceeding. Section 4. No law shall be passed abridging the freedom of speech, of expression, or of the press, or the right of the people peaceably to assemble and petition the government for redress of grievances.

I'm no lawyer but it's clear that there is something seriously wrong with the law. Ten motions for a temporary restraining order have been filed before the Supreme Court and they will meet on Tuesday to listen to the arguments. The law took effect yesterday. So you can imagine what took place. My fellow countrymen were livid. They went to the streets in protest and changed their facebook profile to black in protest.  http://beta.taopo.org/isyu/10/02/2012/online-protests-become-offline-actions-against-ra-10175 It has been picked up by the foreign press. http://globalvoicesonline.org/2012/09/19/philippines-anti-cybercrime-law-threatens-media-freedom/ https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2012/10/dark-day-philippines-government-passes-cybercrime-act http://sg.news.yahoo.com/philippine-websites-hacked-over-cybercrime-law-175219087.html http://news.cnet.com/8301-17852_3-57526494-71/can-you-be-jailed-for-a-facebook-like-in-the-philippines/ http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-19810474 http://www.cnn.com/2012/10/04/world/asia/philippines-cyber-law-protest/index.html http://world.time.com/2012/10/03/must-reads-from-around-the-world-40/ Let's go even further that the Philippines joined the Open Government Partnership in 2011.  It seems that government and politicians can't put a stop to the discussion going on about them and the way they behave and perform in goverment and that their only recourse is to just put a lid on it and put the entire country back in the stone ages. Just recently, a senator was caught plagiarising his speech by the internet community and claimed he did nothing wrong. It was made worse as he did it again a week later. But this time, translating a speech delivered by Sen. Robert F. Kennedy in 1966 into Filipino. Oh yeah, he put the libel clause in.  Now lawmakers are quick to go on camera and state that "if" elected, they will change that provision. It's an election year next year and they need the votes of the public.  Let's look at the numbers. So far, most of the protests I've seen are on Facebook and I've shared a number of them.  According to socialbakers.com  Facebook has almost 30% of the general population of the Philippines or almost everyone with an internet connection.  With more than half of them are eligible voters. How many are registered voters is another issue but is it enough to change their minds? Now for the interesting part. Now what? Sharing Facebook is nice and all but in the end we are all just armchair activists. Sharing, liking and retweeting things we believe our readers and followers should know. But will it change anything? This is an interesting turning point for the country. This internet generation has grown up used to the freedoms that my parents didn't have between the years 1972-1986 when the country was ruled by a dictator. I know my history and what it took to get that freedom back. I am curious if this generation will stand up for their rights.  This is a challenge to our freedom and to our internet. The internet must be free and it is up to us to keep it that way. The government has much to learn from the internet. I would like you to watch ITP Professor Clay Shirky speaking at TED Global this year on what government can learn from the internet and it's users.

item.title: The kitchen sink
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: For 36 hours this week I was watching the kitchen sink that sits in the lounge for purposes that shall reveal itself next week. It's interesting what people do there. Like catching someone leaving their dish in the sink. (Sorry Mick) How these two stayed here from 1 pm (I started watching) until the floor closed. And then some. This morning before the floor opened. To be revealed next week.

item.title: The sound of my room
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: Though a room is tecnically an inanimate object, I see it as a living thing. I try to spend time in my apartment as much as possible since I already spen too much of it in school as it is. My room will slowly breakdown if I do not clean it, repaint it and so on. It would be empty without the furniture or the Tibetan prayer flags that hang from my window. Laughter and the sound of people in the room provide it warmth or other elements that give it personality. This brings me to the readings on how the author thinks how ants, dolphins and even penguins communicate to one another. Understandable that these are animals where there is a level communication not discernable to us humans but between them, there is understanding. It interesting that plants are a bit chided in the discussion of the story since it doesn't seem that plants do not communicate. This brings me to my room. I believe that physical objects are alive. A combination of physical objects may be an organism. Or it could be just my brain attempting to connect everything together.  Which brings me to something I've always wanted to do but couldn't find the time to do it. Record myself in the room without me consciously in the room. The original recording is 8 hours so this is a snippet of eight minutes instead of me sleeping between the hours of 4-5am.

item.title: Ouija board
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: This is not a post about the supernatural. This is actually a post for an idea. I used to work for a large news organization (at least 800 people) and one of the problems with such a large group is personel deployment. Keeping track of hundreds of journalists and assets alongside breaking stories is a superhuman feat. When all the user has to go through is spreadsheet like interface, duplicate assignments and overlapping stories occur. With this problem in mind I thought of aircraft carrier operations, this is where the ouija board comes in.  Up until last year, the US Navy used an analog board inside the operations deck of an aircraft carrier to keep track of everything that is happening on the flight deck. It provides the users a real time snapshot on what's happening on deck. One of the reasons for the navy to stick to such an analog system for tracking one of the most advanced military equipment is that in the event of an attack and the ship is damaged, the ouija board will continue to fucntion.  However, as of last year they have decided to switch to a digital format with some resistance from their end users.  So I was thinking of building a similar thing for newsroom operations. But instead of an aircraft carrier flight deck, I would use a map layer of the city. As news feeds come it, hotspots are generated on the table which identify areas that have the most news reports at that time. Another layer will use the news assets such as reporters, satellites, cameramen and so on to provide the fastest response available. I was thinking of using Processing for this project or OpenFrameworks but it's still a very early idea. I may, or may not build this but this will require much more thought and research.

item.title: The Continuum
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: Back when the internet was new for me and I had just switched jobs, I began to be active in the Star Trek Community. This group is not just a bunch of fans talking about Star Trek. This was a bunch of fans talking about Star Trek with the producers!! This was before blogs, before twitter and social media we came together in IRC. At any time of the day you could go in and chat will fellow trekkers about anything but the one thing that brought people together was Star Trek. Moderators would host trivia contests and I have once won a Trilithium Ribbon for beating everyone in the Star Trek: Deep Space Nine trivia. The biggest perks of this was that occasionally, they would host celebrity chats where fans could ask questions. And on October 30, 1998 there was a special chat with Terry Farrell who played Jadzia Dax on Deep Space Nine and they asked my question! Sadly when CBS purchased Paramount Pictures the Star Trek Continuum team were all fired and the entire site changed. The transcript of the chat is no longer hosted on the official website but it's still mirrored elsewhere. As with everything with life and it's fleeting moments, I had to move on beyond Star Trek. So it came as a shock when I found out that the husband and wife, Ben and Syl who were such a big part of the community passed away. It feels eerily creepy as our sites were hosted on Geocities before, they have passed, but their website still lives on. This prompted me to immortalize the experience. I first thought of printing the question and answer on paper. But then I've done that already. I wanted it to a bit more special. Since I moved apartments, I haven't put anything on the walls yet. They look so empty and bare. I also want only items on the wall that I really like of course but if possible something I made. I decided to etch it on a sheet of plexi I had lying around.  This will hang on my wall.

item.title: A sense of direction
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: This week's assignment has made me look at the different ways I actually get around. Though now I spend time searching for places to eat and directions on Google Maps or my iPhone, there are still some basic skills and some jargon I use in order to get around and identify locations. Let's begin with the subway. Before coming to ITP, the last time I extensively used the subway was in 1997. So after the events of 9/11, the New York transit system drastically changed. Thus train routes that I once used are no longer running in the same place. So we all know more or less the NYC subway system.  By sheer text data without the line representation or colors I know that I can get to school from my apartment on the Downtown N.  Or I can use the DwQ -N, R-N, 4/5-6. I can get to JFK from ITP using the Up6-R-E. Or just walk to W4th street and just take the E all the way. Even though Google Maps attempts to include an estimated travel time for their destinations, unless I am in Germany, I don't think the times of arrival and departure of the trains are accurate. I may not have an app or an actual map, but I do have a system that I can write down that can be understood in less than 5 minutes. Now for another way of looking at cities. Race tracks. View Larger Map I'm a big fan of autoracing having grown up on that influence and it made me think of a trip to Monaco. It was my first time in the principality and it was very disorienting once we got out the train station. My father wanted to get to Casino Square.  We were getting nowhere arguing with each other until it dawned on him and asked me in what race corner is Casino Square to which I replied, the 3rd corner and that were were on the turn 1. So we proceeded to head towards the direction of turn 3. Most classic race tracks in Europe are partially built over city roads such as Circuit de la Sarthe in Le Mans. and the new Singapore F1 race track,   All the turns are played over and over again on television which makes identification of streets and landmarks quite easy without a physical map. Another way of getting around New York is through Woody Allen's films. Most Woody Allen films are shot entirely in New York and can provide a great guide to the city.

item.title: Final Project Idea for Nature of Code
item.dc:creator: mdelamerced
item.content:encoded: work in progress from Melissa A. dela Merced on Vimeo. I'm thinking of expanding my midterm idea for the final project. My project is largely inspired by a scene in Star Wars' Return of the Jedi. Everyone almost always wants to be the Jedi and no one wants to be in the dark side. My project involves bolts of lightning or particles come from the hands as seen in this clip (before the emperor dies of course). Or maybe in Dragon Ball Z. For the midterms I used the hand gesture to track my hand movements using the simpleopenNI library for Processing. For the finals I'll be using the skeletal tracking to get both hands. By putting the hands together it will increase activity of the particles surround the hands. And by pointing the hands in a area in the screen will direct the 'bolts of Sith Lord power' across the direction it is pointing at. Lightning will be generated using fractal math. I think. Which we will learn in a few weeks.
